email/call from Mr Volk:
Dan Volk
12:09 PM (3 minutes ago)
to me

Hi Faye , just wanted to let you know I have recently had my last visit with Aptiva Health as well as my last visit with Resolves physical therapy
Both places say I am as good as I’m going to get. I do still have some restriction in my neck movement and some pain and weakness in my shoulder
I did have my surgery to remove the brain tumor. I briefly spoke to the surgeon,Dr. Sun, in summary he said he did not know if there was a way to tell if the impact from the accident caused any of the problems with the tumor specifically the headaches. However, the day of the accident I went to an immediate care/emergency room with my injuries including headache. I had not had problems with headaches before the accident but had then since the accident all the way up until the time of the tumor surgery and have not had headaches sense. 
On January 18 I have a follow up MRI for the remainder of the tumor that could not be removed and a follow up with the surgeon in February

I also have all the medical records related to the brain tumor prior to the surgery if they are needed I can provide them in order to avoid having to pay the hospital to reproduce them. Thank you for your attention please feel free to contact me at any time #cc

Pls let me know if there is any further information I can provide
If the medical records for the tumor are needed I have already received those records up to the time of the surgery I obtained them to be sent off for a second opinion regarding treatment options. Thank you for your help #cc

episode_body:
On 2024-08-26, Aaron Whaley emailed Kimberle Pishke:

Case: Daniel-W-Volk-MVA-09-24-2021
Client: Daniel W Volk
__Dan Volk #047060829__
Kim, thank you for the call earlier. I listened to your message and I
wanted to email you in the hopes of clearing up our position. You made a
statement in the voicemail that is not supported by any documentation. You
said that the headaches were caused by neck pain, which led to the MRI that
found the meningioma. No medical record supports that conclusion. A brain
MRI for radiating neck pain is not normal. I want to give you a
hypothetical.
Dan lives his life normally. Dan doesn't have any neck pain. However, Dan
has a C3-C4 herniated disc in his neck. This herniated disc is not causing
any stenosis and there are no symptoms from the herniated disc. If this was
found on an MRI, the doctors would not perform surgery to correct it since
it was asymptomatic. No doctor would be able to say within a reasonable
degree of medical certainty that the herniated disc would ever become
symptomatic. Now, Dan gets into an accident. He was hit from behind. After
the accident, he begins to have symptoms related to the herniated disc. The
Asymptomatic has become Symptomatic. His doctor then performs surgery to
correct the herniated disc.
In the above example, you would have no problem agreeing that the accident
caused an aggravation of a preexisting condition. There would be no issue
with relating the surgery to correct the herniated disc to the accident.
Replace herniated disc with mengioma in the example and you have the exact
same thing as here. There is no way to know if the menengioma would have
ever become symptomatic. It may have sat there in his head, doing nothing.
However, after the trauma of the accident, the mengioma became syptomatic
and had to be removed. That means the need for removal was caused by the
accident, just as the herinated disc repair was in the hypothetical.
You cannot think of the meningioma as if it were some cancerous brain
tumor. If it was, then yes, it would have to come out or be treated in some
way at some point. The accident could then be viewed as a happy misfortune.
A meningioma is not the same. They are not cancers. They do not grow
aggressively. They do not have to be removed if they are not causing
symptoms.
Here is a link to some information on Meningioma treatment. Notice the
first paragraph: "Meningioma treatment is not always necessary, especially
in situations where the tumors are small, noncancerous, and not causing the
patient any discomfort. Benign meningiomas may be addressed with “watchful
waiting,” in which physicians carefully monitor a patient with regular
imaging scans and physical exams but do not make any treatment
recommendations unless symptoms develop or the tumor starts to spread."
https://www.moffitt.org/cancers/meningioma/treatment/
I have attached the 12/13/2021 Norton Cancer Institute record as well.
"This lesion was discovered upon headaches after motor vehicle accident."--
Kim, We know this to be true. Prior to the accident, Dan had an
asymptomatic meningioma. There is no evidence that it would have needed
removal at any future time. After the accident, the meningioma became
symptomatic and needed to be removed. BECASUE THE ACCIDENT CAUSED THE
MENINGIOMA TO BECOME SYMPTOMATIC.
Thanks.
Aaron Whaley
Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Ln
Louisville, KY 40222
502-583-4022
author: Aaron Whaley

episode_body:
On 2024-08-27, Aaron Whaley emailed Filevine Project Email Address:

Case: Daniel-W-Volk-MVA-09-24-2021
Client: Daniel W Volk
__Re: Dan Volk #047060829 Claim#:047060829-04__
Kim, thank you for your time and thoughtful response. I will address your
response in order.
1. You state that Mr. Volk's headaches could be from the cervicle injury,
and his doctors do not attribute his headaches to the meningioma.
Yes, cervical injuries can result in referred pain to the head. However,
even if his neck injury caused some headache symptoms, his doctor states
that the meningioma is the cause. Additionally, Mr. Volk had other symptoms
related to the meningioma that he did not have before. On 12/13.21, Dr.
Sorah notes that Dan is having intermittent left hemibody sensation changes
most predominant in the leg. Mr. Völk saw Dr. Sun on 01/22/2022. Dr. Sun
notes headaches as well as intermittent paresthesias in his left lower
extremity as symptoms of the meningioma. What is important is that before
the accident there were no headaches, no parasthesia, and no sensation
issues. After the accident, the symptoms develop. Additionally, I just saw
that the MRI also showed a small amount of edema, or swelling around the
meningioma. None of the Dr's address the significance of the edema, but
that sure does sound to me like it could be the result of the trauma, which
is why he is now symptomatic.
2. Mr. Volk could do nothing or have surgery. Mr. Volk chose surgery, so
it's not related to the accident.
Unless a person is in an ER, all surgery is a choice. A person with a
herniated disc has a choice for a spinal fusion or do nothing. If they
choose surgery, that would not mean the accident did not lead to the choice
and therefore the surgery. Additionally, in the present case, Mr. Volk did
have a choice but his doctor recommended surgery. Dr. Sun on 4/29/22 lays
out options of continued surveillance, craniotomy, or radiation therapy. He
then goes on to recommend craniotomy.
3. You claim that he would have had to have the meningioma removed
eventually.
His doctor giving him the option of continuing surveillance directly
contradicts that. You cite a paragraph from Mt. Sinai Hospital's website
for the proposition that meningioma must be removed. Yet, on that same
website, on the page about treatment of meningioma, there is this
paragraph:If your tumor is growing slowly and does not affect your health,
we may choose to observe your tumor at scheduled intervals rather than
treat it immediately. We might schedule you for regular magnetic resonance
imaging scans to
monitor the tumor's growth."
https://www.mountsinai.org/care/neurosurgery/services/meningiomas/treatments-procedures
So, your own source says that sometimes just watching and waiting is an
option. Just like Mr. Volk's Dr.'s.
At the end of the day, these are the uncontroverted facts.
1. Prior to the accident, Mr. Volk did not have a problem with headaches or
leg parasthesia.
2. After the accident, Mr. Volk had persistent headaches that led to a
brain MRI.
3. The brain MRI revealed a small meningioma.
4. Mr. Volk's neurologist and cancer doctor both relate that the headaches
and the parasthesia he was experiencing were due to the meningioma.
5. Mr. Volks neurologist recommended surgical removal of the
meningoma, which Mr. Volk agreed to.
6. Mr. Volk undergoes a craniotomy.
So, either as a manner of great coincidence, Mr. Volk has a meningioma that
is completely asymptomatic until immediately following a car accident and
wholly unrelated to the car accident; he then begins to have symptoms and
subsequent removal of the meningioma
or
Mr. Volk has an asymptomatic meningioma that becomes symptomatic after the
trauma of the car accident and has to have it removed.
Thank you. Have a great day.

__Re: Re: Dan Volk #047060829 Claim#:047060829-04__
Kim,
I never said that the accident caused the tumor. The accident does not need
to cause the tumor for it to be compensable. The accident needs to cause
the symptoms from the tumor to appear. He was completely asymptomatic prior
to the accident. The force of the accident caused the tumor to shift
slightly and that leads to the symptoms. The fact that the tumor is now
symptomatic is why it had to be removed. This is exactly like a
pre-existing herniated disc that is asymptomatic prior to an accident. The
accident causes the herniated disc to shift and it is now pressing on
nerves and causing symptoms.
The day of the accident Dan goes to OSF Prompt Care. He does not report
neck pain. He does report a headache along the left temporal and parietal
region. Headaches from whiplash or referred neck pain are most commonly at
the base of the skull near the neck. Dan had a headache that was in the
left temproal lobe and left parietal lobe. Basically the side of the head
near the ear to the top of the head in the middle. Not at all what you
would expect from a whiplash injury. It is, however, what you would expect
from a headache caused by the meningioma. His headaches were caused by the
meningioma. Not whiplash. There were no headaches before the accident. So
the accident caused the headaches from the meningioma.
You keep mentioning that the meningioma was an incidental finding as if
that has some relevance. It isn't. It just means it was not something they
were looking for when they did the brain MRI.
